thread.title: At Thailand's veggie festival, only flesh of the devout is harmed
thread.title_full: At Thailand's veggie festival, only flesh of the devout is harmed

author: DAVID LONGSTREATH, Associated Press
title: At Thailand's veggie festival, only flesh of the devout is harmed
text:
At Thailand's veggie festival, only flesh of the devout is harmed DAVID LONGSTREATH, ASSOCIATED PRESS Last updated 11:54, October 21 2015 Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images Taylor Weidman/Getty Images AP AP AP AP AP AP 
Devotees parade through the streets as firecrackers go off in Phuket, Thailand. The annual Vegetarian Festival is celebrated by the Thai Chinese on Phuket Island. During the festival, many participants enter a trance-like state and participate in ritual mutilation as a sign of devotion and veneration to the Nine Emperor Gods. 
A devotee in a trance-like state hands out offerings of fruit in Phuket, Thailand. 
A devotee has his cheeks pierced during the annual Vegetarian Festival. 
Participants parade through the streets as firecrackers go off. 
Devotees take part in a fire walking ritual. 
Devotees take part in a fire walking ritual. 
A devotee sets of firecrackers before a fire walking ritual. 
Devotees take part in a fire walking ritual. 
Devotees gather at Bang Neow Shrine. 
A devotee prays at an altar at Bang Neow Shrine. 
A devotee has decorative needle piercings placed all over his body while in a trane-like state at Bang Neow Shrine. 
Thai children offer prayers in Phuket, Thailand, as they gather for a street procession at the Vegetarian festival. 
Devotees to the Chinese shrine of Bang Liao have fireworks exploded over them as they carry a portable shrine during a street procession in Phuket, Thailand. 
Devotees to the Chinese shrine Ban Tha Rue in Phuket, Thailand, work themselves into a trance. 
A devotee to the Chinese shrine of Bang Liao has spikes pierced through his face as he walks in a street procession in Phuket, Thailand. 
Chinese emperor gods spikes are displayed outside the Chinese shrine of Ban Tha Rue in Phuket, Thailand. 
Devotees to the Chinese shrine of Bang Liao walk in a street procession in Phuket, Thailand. 1 of 17 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
WARNING: Some of the images on the gallery above may offend 
Thailand's Vegetarian Festival is more than sprouts and tofu - it's an assault on the senses, and for the most devout, on the body itself. 
The most striking element of the nine-day Taoist celebration has little to do with food. In sacred rituals, devotees known as "Mah Song" or "Spirit Horses" work themselves into trances to have all manner of items pierced through their cheeks, from daggers and swords to a bicycle. Then they dance as massive strings of fireworks explode all around them. AP 
A devotee enters a trance before being pierced at Thailand's Vegetarian festival. 
The annual festival in Phuket has become a tourist attraction, with several large, noisy processions complete with fireworks, gongs and drums passing through the streets. Many Phuket residents have Chinese ancestors, and devotees to the many Chinese temples on the island parade their shrines' emperor gods on hand-carried carriages. 
The Vegetarian Festival begins on the eve of the ninth lunar month of the Chinese calendar and is observed primarily in Southeast Asian countries, including Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Myanmar. It traces its origins to the early 1800s, when a troupe of Chinese actors on tour in Phuket fell ill.
